reviewText:
I love how the game specifically instructs you that you don't need EVERY FEATURE in a game in the tutorial, and then releases a game development game so weighed down by useless features it is positively unplayable.

Playing in the stock market, and decorating your home, and employee morale, but a lot of it doesn't really actually work, and setting vacation time?  I mean what kind of game is this exactly?

Limit your scope, this might be very detailed, but it is not fun, and the interface of needing to navigate to different buildings and then navigate to some sub screen just to do anything is time consuming and annoying.

Why do people keep making these strategy games with incredibly tedious theatre of the mind interfaces".  It seems like a German thing
date:
and it is atrocious.  Have a freaking responsive dropdown menu.

EDIT AFTER MORE PLAYTIME

I tried to give the game a second chance since the developer responded to the review.  I still would not reccomend it.

The tool tips and gameplay cues about what happens when you say advertise with your game
recommended: versus advertise for the company as a whole are not remotely clear.  The lack of save functionality is crippling in realtime game with poor and non customizable autopause features.  Trying to get the information about say what games are popular is on a totally different screen than the one that offer syou contract and it 3 or 4 clicks away.\n\nThe whole bank makes little sense
hoursPlayed: the loan terms are all wrong.  You ae only charged interest once
voteText: it is not amortized.  So you can get a $100k loan for 1 year for a one time 7%
helpfulPercent: or over 25 years for a one time 30%...which do you think is a better deal?  Loans don't actually work that way.  A 1 year 7% loan indeed costs you ~$107k
votesHelpful: but a 25 year 30% loan costs you $750k NOT $130.\n\nThere is a good game here somewhere with a better interface and so more clear tool tips and fat cutting of needless features and more focus on the game development portion of game
votesTotal: but uggh what a chore to play right now."

reviewText: Aside from launch/early access hiccups (audio language mismatch, missing text, etc), the control is abysmal: the interface requires you to constantly switch between rooms and needlessly navigate redundant menus. It also lacks necessary indicators (you have to go to development room, then to development menu to view development progress), there are no tips as on estimated effect (for example, on copy protection), and the overall gameplay is not only non-intuitive, but also redundant (like having to find a proper publisher for game GENRE, and there might be none at the time).\n\nAll in all, it might be fixed somewhat, but I do not believe any major issues will be addressed, and thus do not advise to buy this game.

reviewText:
This game has potential, but everything just looks bad and feels bad. It barely felt like I was making progress, even after the tutorial I was still confused (by the way the tutorial is pretty long, doesn't save your progress during it, and is ridiculously long.) The UI reminds me of a mid-90s mystery game.

It's nice with the details and complexity, but just doesn't pull it off correctly.

The biggest problem is the clutter and general unkemptness of it all. I make a game, but wait, I need to go to a completely different room to research things...ok did that, now lets start...oh wait, I don't have the necessary employees, lets go to a completely different building to hire people...Ok hired a graphic designer, programmer, and audio technician...can I make my game yet? Yes, but make sure you pick your console...ok PC, alright now lets wait for development...done, now lets pack your box.....erh wtf am I putting in the box (better remember that tutorial.)

Finally, packed and ready to go, lets order it! Oh wait you need to get a publisher...after hunting for a publisher in every building (oh the lawyer got it.) Let's order! Awesome now let's get a contract....a huge search later and NONE do my genre?!? WTF I can't put my games on the shelf because they only sell RPGS?! -close-

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Release Review

Game music: a combination of elevator/disco. Awful just turn it off.

You get to be impersonated by three robots, a blond, a redhead and a brunette. Why only three I don't understand. NO characters would have been vetter

You get two game choices campaign or endless. OK.
I chose campaign. I made SURE the old game folder was deleted in Steam/common but when the tutorial pops up it started at #4 learning all about the marketing and PR department.

INSTANTLY this character speaking Germish babble atarts to talk over the tutorial WHY WHY WHY??? What is the point of that??? WHY NOT JUST READ THE TUTORIAL TO US? Bad bad choice dev.

You're looking at a nice big office with a nice big LED monitor and three other doors. Wait. LED monitor in 1980? Really? OK I'll go with it.

Now comes the really disconcerting part after Babbling robot's voice stops, HIS LIPS KEEP MOVING. I let it sit for about five minutes and they kept moving like A ROBOT in a German PC game. He wants me to open the map and select the Law department. problem is WHERE IS THE MAP TO OPEN???

Let's try M.M doesn't work. If I stop and go back it's just going to start here again, So it's click on everything time. Crap RIGHT clicking on the window doesn't bring up a map it brings up a view of the buildings around you AND NOTHING IS LABELED ANYWHERE. A big yellow arrow points at a building yay. But no labels.

The next instructions ar After you pick a lawyer the publisher contracts are automatically displayed". WAIT how much does a lawyer cost? WHY do I need a lawyer? Can't I self publish? This is not going well.

From the arrow lawyers are on the ground floor. Figures
date:
bottom feeders on the bottom. WAIT I DIDN'T PICK A LAWYER it immediately threw me into the publisher's area WTF???  "Now select the tutorial-publisher contract and conclude it" Conclude what? HOW?

You click on "sign" the babling ♥♥♥♥♥ doesn't tell you that "Jango krakenrobbins" as he said. "Since I ALREADY DEVELOPED A GAME"I did? OK lets just go with mr. babbling Germish.

OK so a game was completed and I have to keep in mind deadlines and genres. Really? Deadlines? Shouldn't this be like kinda open ended? So a message pops up telling me I passed the game but when it disappears I can't recover it. Grrrrrrr. What is "passed the game" mean. grrrrrr.

Now it's time to go to the "map" (window) and select the publicity? ooohh nice
hoursPlayed: what? I can book campaigns booths of r  fairs and do interviews? WHY why not HIRE someone to do that???  Here's the problem

BABBLER STARTED TO SPEND MORE TIME ON ADVERTISING THAN ON THE CORE GAME I GAVE UP. This game is a nightmare. There's no continituity and the polish was done with corse sandpaper. Sunlight charges WAY WAY WAY too much for this game. Buy GameCorp DX for $5 by game dev tycoon

reviewText:
The game has potential. The tech seems to hit market at the right time. But there are to many game breaking bugs. Several times I had major losses because I can't hand in a commished game that they accepted specs for (quality way above demand). Also taxes became way to high as I used 1 mill on investments, but only the 1 mill + intrest was calculated. so I had to pay tax as if I earned over 1 mill instead of tax only of the intrest.

As an economical game not letting you earn money were you are supposed to drops my intrest totally. Avoid!

reviewText:
Game Tycoon 2 is a tycoon game, developed by Sunlight Games, about making your own game with your own video game company. Sounds super fun right? Because you know, you're a gamer, so that means you gotta have the game about making games for gamers, right, right? Well, not with this game. If you really want a game development game that's good, five dollars less, and more polished, get Game Dev Tycoon.

Game Tycoon 2 has interesting concepts. You have your office, development office and the accessibility to a bank, lawyers, an advertisement agency, the local university, a shopping mall, your own home, and also a production warehouse to create box art and ship the games. You better look at the tutorials because I didn't on my first play-through and had no idea what I was doing. I assumed they'd teach you through out the game, like other tycoon games do, but they didn't. Aside from the tutorials, they have a “campaign”, and an endless mode. Now, I say “campaign”, because it's a “mission” where you have to achieve one goal. There is no way of telling you that you've failed either, you just have to go bankrupt.

I think the main problem with this game is that it's very unclear on what to do because it's not like other tycoon games I've played. The different offices and places available are cool, in concept, but don't really execute well. You can sign a contract to have a company publish or distribute your game and it has a deadline, but you can't make your workers work faster unless you make them stop or train them, which already takes too long. I don't get the process of researching technologies, they still cost the same when you're trying to develop your game. And the main thing that bugged me was the UI. I don't get how it could be that buggy. It was the most difficult thing to assign members of your staff to projects. They made it so complex, for some reason.

The graphics weren't a big deal to me in this game, but I think the character art is pretty weird. Just saying. Now, I sound like I hate the game but I think it could definitely be a good game. The concepts of being able to make your own box art, sign up employees from the local university, advertise your company or game, make contracts, get a loan and buy shares of other companies, surprised me. It has the concepts that could make a great game. But, it's just so hard to get things done with the UI, to me. It makes the game hard to navigate.

The sound of this game is, whatever, average. I can't see myself buying this game for 15 dollars either. Maybe 5. This game just needs to be easier to learn, easier to navigate and have some extra functionalities like speeding up the process of creating the game, despite the quality of the game worsening like in Game Dev Tycoon. With that and other things, this game could definitely be something worth 15 dollars and have good replayability.

By Hakuyer

reviewText:
* First of all, this is not a Game Dev Tycoon! These two games may share similar topic, but the concepts are different. *

I'm recommending this game, because I enjoyed both first and second game in series, and there are only few games of this genre available. Sure, it has it's pros and cons, but I think that true fans will find a way to enjoy it.

The game it self may be clunky, with not so sharp graphics, but underneath it is a true tycoon game. Tutorials may be better, but at the end it is us who needs to discover the whole game (yes, game developers wanted to be mysterious).
I struggled at first, like in the first part of the franchise, but ultimately I found the way to become a true game tycoon".

I'm happy that there is still support for the game
date: and that my voice was heard
recommended: so I'm waiting for the promises to be delivered on the next patch.\n\nOne thing I don't like is that the game development was spread too much. Developers tried to add "gimmicks" but I think that time/resources could be better spent on core parts of the game. Gambling on investments is cool
hoursPlayed: but stock market is too shallow. Apartment is a feature from the previous part of the game and I still don't see it's purpose.\n\nAt the end
voteText: despite all the flaws

reviewText:
Endlich mal wieder eine umfangreiche Wirtschaftssimulation mit einem interessanten Hintergrund, bei dem sich jeder
Gamer gleich wie zuhause fühlt. Es ist zudem ziemlich spannend, mal die andere Seite zu verfolgen - nämlich die Seite
eines Games-Publishers und dabei alle Aufgaben zu bewerkstelligen, die einem so als Publisher Tag für Tag begegnen.
Das Spiel bietet für eine Wirtschaftsimulation eigentlich alles, was von dieser Art Spiel für gewöhnlich erwartet wird:
einen sehr realistisch anmutenden Wirtschaftskreislauf, eine enorme Vielfalt an Einstellungsmöglichkeiten, eine spannende Thematik und das Gefühl, bei einer bestimmten Vorgehensweise auch die entsprechenden Ergebnisse zu erzielen. Zudem gibt es ein umfangreiches Tutorial, bei dem dem Spieler das Spiel Schritt für Schritt erklärt wird. Für Freunde und Liebhaber von Wirtschaftssimulationen lohnt sich der Kauf des Spieles allemal. Mir hat es bisher viel Spaß gemacht!

reviewText:
First off to anyone who thinks this has any relation to Game Dev Tycoon by much loved Greenheart games.

It has no relation. (This is the sequal to the much older Game Tycoon)

secondly this game is early access, you can expect the game to be unpolished, broken and to generaly not be super user friendly to start with (hence it's early access... you know unfinished)

Thirdly given the background and limitaintions of this development team the translation is more than adequatefor what you need to know.


now the slight bad bits i picked up on from my time on the game to date.

Sadly the toutorials are a little broken from what i played and need alot of work.

Customization also seems to be a little low on content.




in short this review is made to dispell some of the people interested in this game. Its not game dev tycoon nor is it meant to be. what it is is an unfinished sequel to a game predating GDT with heaps of potential and a dedicated development team. certainly worth the investmont.

reviewText:
Overally this game is quite good with fascinating idea. However, there are some cons that actually ruins my gameplay experience. Hope they can fix it asap.
1. Employees cannot filtered or sorted so it makes me hard to find the good quality people in my LONG list in a short time.
2. Btw I can only assign employees to the projects one by one. At the late game I have more than 100 programmers but I still can only assign them ONE BY ONE. Hope they can add one assign all" button.
3. Nobody will buy my engines after I made my 3rd engine. Is the others too good in producing their own engines or they   won't buy my cheaper engines?
4. The online server system is quite annoying
date: especially web browser and mobile games. They NEVER make profits.\n5. Stock market is just too hard to ply with. Seldom earn profits as the listed companies' values keep dropping.\n6. The home is literally a home
recommended: but you can't do anything inside."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's very very early days for Game Tycoon 2. The foundations are there for a brilliant game but I will stress it is no where near ready for a full game experience (Which is obvious as it's in early access).

I played for an hour or so and as far as I could tell you could not actually publish your game yet or go in 75% of the buildings. The career has around 21 missions but I only got through a few (which were tutorials).

If you are interested in watching a 20 minute video preview I made then here is the link:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XwaB6YRZEyk

I would personally wait a few months and see how this game turns out. I have a great feeling for it. I will also mention that the language has english text but the voice overs are in German.

Thanks!

reviewText:
This game is fun once you learn how to make money.  It can be a little tricky when you first start playing, but once you figure it out its a blast.  There are a lot of things to keep you busy while developing.  The strategy is  key.  I spend hours playing without realizing it.  At least until my wife let's me know :)

More Detailed Review:

The more updates they put out, the better this game gets.  There is a lot of strategy in planning your next contract to take on.

Some games only require 29% quality, but you don't want your reputation to drop by putting out a low quality game, so you put your programmers to work and spend a little extra money on features to make it a good game.  However you didn't quite get the Difficulty right, so your quality is only 50% which gives you a rating of 35.  You spend a few thousand $ on advertising but no one is buying your game.  Quick, go accept another contract and try to do better.  Wait, my company reputation is getting low.  Need to go advertise my company before all my games tank out!

Crap, 12:00am and I have to get up for work at 6:00am.  I will do better on my next contract when my brain has rested.  Goodnight ....

Woke up at 5:00am, time for one more contract before work :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game Tycoon 2:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Are you up to the task of being the CEO of your own developing and producing game company?

Game Tycoon 2 is really in its infancy at this stage (Early Access) and you will be able to play the first tutorial which gives you a really good understanding of how to start a game; what you have to do and who you have to hire for the job at hand.

The graphics are good and cartoon-style which is fun. As it is presented right now, this game shows great potential with plenty of depth with a lot options, such as the type of game you want to produce, what type of resolution, sounds, engines and more! If you are like me and enjoy a simulation/strategy game, you must keep a close look at Game Tycoon 2.

I will do a full review when more content will be added to the game. I am really looking forward to this one.

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Reminder* - This game is still in early access. you can watch my gameplay on https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_0LNTsAsXQ
--------------------

Despite the lack of content, from being in early access, the game played well.  It is certainly not complete.  The tutorial voice overs were not in English and I found no way to change this.  I did appreciate they allowed subtitles as an option, which still makes the tutorial playable.  I found that I couldn't publish a game, since it is not being implemented until launch?  Either way the game has potential and once fully complete I can fully review the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I gave it a thumbs up because this game has potential.
Knowing that this game is still in early access and improving with updaes, i will only mention the missing things that need to be added or fixed in order for this game to be competitive.

Missing things that must be added quickly:

- Ability to see the final quality of the game and all information related to it
- More UI sounds and feedback
- Ability to know the approximate price that needs to be put for a game release
- A button to press to say Release Game" when choosing the right distributer and price
- More notifications for when a game finishes production
- A good tutorial
- More bug fixes and balancing


This game has potential if pushed in the right direction...
So devs
date: don't disappoint.\nThis is the old school meets new age of game tycoon games
recommended: for an old school gamer like me
hoursPlayed: this could be best of the 2 worlds if developed properly"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a game developer my self I know how hard it is to develop games of ORIGIONAL content. This game has the ability to be something spectacular, You probably have gone a little over board with the 3d graphics side of things, it reminds me about of simcity 3 map. I would personally prefer say crisp clean 2d graphics and a better game play engine. remember this is a simulation sandbox. the more 3d in it the heavier the gpu load.

Plus by having 2d graphics you open the door to it running better on mobile device. Also you could implement a feature later on upon developing consoles that allow a infinite number of upgrades buy the upgrade and the cost just adding + 1 for the upgrade and + X amount + X for the cost.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all: This game is in EARLY ACCESS. It means that the game is still in development, in case of Game Tycoon 2 it's even under heavy development. Around 60% of the game are missing still, but the Developer is working on it. Just recently the big update to 0.2 released, adding several new features for you to test.

Anyway, so far you can't do much in it, Early Access still, but you can see what it is possible or will be possible. You can create Engines, Games, Sequels, Patches, Demos, research new Technologies etc.

Planned is even to buy other game companies, getting on the stock market etc.

Really, give the game a chance and give the Devloper the money they need to continue working on it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been given this game to do a review on it on Youtube. And I like the game, sure it has some minor bugs and needs some polishing up, but the amount of detail and the depth in wich you can make the games are awsome! And for this price!? If you like tycoon games this is most def worth a buy!

Some of the cons I found in the game though:
Even on easy mode the game is really hard and you can not release a game without any contracts, wich takes away a lot of freedom, but I imagine that that will change once you've made enough money ;)

I like it and I look forward to the full release! Good job Sunlight Games!

reviewText:
Disclaimer: A key was provided to us for review purposes.

Hello everybody, Shaun Meyers here from Universal Gaming Reviews to bring you a summary of our review for Game Tycoon 2 by Sunlight Games and Kiss Ltd. You can read our full review for the game here: https://www.universalgamingreviews.com/game-tycoon-2-overview-and-review/

To start the summary I'll be honest and say that I wasn't really sure if I was going to enjoy the game going into the review because I'm pretty skeptical of post 2005 Tycoon games and have played very few that really wowed me. I still don't think the game matches up to the likes of Zoo Tycoon 2, The Movies or Rollercoaster Tycoon but what's available is quite fun if you're a fan of micromanaging type games.

The game puts you in the role of a game developer trying to reach the top of the market starting in 1980 and going all the way to 2050. The game's main mode is endless mode which allows you freely create games, manage your development studio and keep track of everything. The game has a suprirising amount of depth to it and there's a ton of stuff to manage. It took me a couple games to get the hang of things initially through trial and error.

The game is surprisingly addictive and I had quite a lot of fun playing it even though I don't think it's the best tycoon game I've ever played. With some improvement it could be excellent and if you're a fan of management style games it's worth checking out but it might not be something everyone will enjoy.

Thanks a lot for reading our summary and full review folks, happy gaming!

-Shaun Meyers (Kyo Akiara) out!
